author: Rollmottle
content:
Been trying to think of a way in to the question about what I did without being completely frustrating or giving a list of moves that don't mean anything outside of the context of being in my chair, hearing what and how I hear.

This process for this song is like any other...listen for what the song needs and act accordingly. That's the frustrating answer but it's also true. What did you do? "I mastered it." lol

But I know that's not what you're asking. For a track like this, I'm primarily focused on the vocal and how it's sitting and feeling. The vocal performance is incredibly dynamic and intimate. This one had some ringy stuff through 2.5k and in the upper mid range that I felt was detracting from the "fireside" intimacy. The goal was to take off some of the edge without stepping on the presence. That was a combo of RX and EQ. 

On this song, I did an analog pass because I am usually able to manage to get the balance of presence and de-edge I'm looking for very quickly. Since time was of the essence here, that was the move. Couple of moves on Equilibrium digitally before the Gyraf and Porter Grinder in the analog chain. The "trickiest" thing I did here was flip the Porter Grinder into M/S to bring the vocal closer into the center (by cutting!) and to push the mellotron and atmospherics to the sides (by boosting). All very subtle stuff.

So, there were some moves here, but the moves were all in service of the feeling the song was telling me it needed. We talk a lot about monitoring here. When you can connect to the song and walk around inside of it, it's much easier to know what you need to do (or not to do) to bring it to life.

author: hebakadry
content: As far as the Atmos vs Vinyl debate…vinyl has an amazing organic culture that has spanned decades especially in the electronic and techno scene…unlike Atmos…a multi channel film format shoehorned by a bunch of corporations to sell their shitty proprietary headphones.  If one more person tries to shill the “stereo is vintage” debate, I will gouge them in the eyes.   Stereo rules…and it’s withstood all the changes this industry has seen because it’s FREE when Alan Blumlien's patent ran out and everyone eventually adopted it…it was not proprietary…and asking the consumer to add one speaker was not a huge ask.  Whereas now, with Atmos…I dunno…it’s depressing.  It's riddled with problems including their horrible horrible binaural algorithm which will continue to change and possibly improve while the engineers that make the records will have absolutely no say in said changes.  I think I wouldn't have had a problem with Atmos if they didn't force the binaural format because it takes the craft out of the medium and you end up spending half the time trying to remotely match the stereo version.  People are making money off of it, but it’s just NOT the artist.  I haven’t met a single artist that was actually excited about Atmos.  Like truly excited about it.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Hey @Gerhard Westphalen I don’t have time to read the replies so a quick summary of how I do it, sorry if it’s repeating 

1) Don’t take the limiter off, on many modern projects the music will be unrecognizable without it and it's what the artist approved. I typically reduce the limiting amount around 2dB, sometimes more sometimes less. I’ll also re balance clipper and limiter relationships

2) Don’t do any pre-emptive processing with the exceptions perhaps of paying a little extra care if it’s a project with heavy sibilance. Don’t mono the bass, don’t change the EQ etc 

3) Make a single WAV file of each side, and a set of timing notes that show where each track starts and the length so the cutting engineer can place the track banding / markers

4) I like to highlight anomalies that may present a challenge for cutter but it’s not necessary

author: hebakadry
content: Hey, pretty stoked about this new plugin.  Safe to say there hasn’t been much innovation in the lathe world until this plugin came around…was checking it out a bit in the beta testing phase…for those who aren’t cutting engineers the reference edition is absolutely amazing.  You can get a general sense of how your master will sound to cut and even audition various turntables and cartridges to see how it could sound.  Better language and tools when you’re communicating with your cutting engineer as well.  It also has an amazing visual emulation so you can actually see what’s going on with your grooves.  This is such a special plugin…i don’t get behind a lot of stuff but this is pretty game changing, esp for mastering engineers that don’t cut but actually care about the translation to LP. It was developed with Helmut Erler who was at Dubplates for many years…really amazing dude and friend of mine.  He's cut some really important techno records.  I think the visualization of the cutter head and the grooves will start to make sense to a lot of people that are a bit in the dark about cutting and modulation and how program material can really affect how things sound ultimately…also how you process your master esp when it goes to plants that do in house cuts that are a bit on the safe/boring side.  You can get ahead and provide a master that counteracts some of the wide processing moves they make to avoid distortion at all cost.  Also send your client a ref of what your cut could sound esp when people push back on super long programs that don't translate well https://www.tokyodawn.net/tdr-simulathe-ref/

author: Paris Lee
content:
I’m not really qualified to speak from any technical standpoint of anything discussed here, especially among the giants and don’t want to look stupid …but as someone who DJ’d House, Techno, Drum and Bass etc back in the late 90’s as a teenager in LA on Vinyl (I’m 45 now), watched the transfer to CD’js…(no idol of mine has touched a vinyl in 20 years) and masters for modern EDM artists, I feel like I can speak with some authority about, I dunno, *something*…Back in those days, I guess Ill just say there were a lot of factors that influenced what sounded so good about that era, and what producers did then. The dynamics, combined with the *type of low frequency* content of those genres at that time, along with DJ’s who knew what the fuck they were doing, along with sound crews who worked the rave circuit and were continually hired and worked with the same DJ’s, all contributed so much to this magic rave Vinyl era.
There’s nothing that touched those deep kickass lows back then, But That was the style! 
So much has changed. Producers back then got their loudness from pushing analog desks into the red, Simple Mackie desks, stuff like that. But We moved to an all digital world. I remember when the first pioneer digital DJ mixers came out, I’d put a vinyl on and just be like…this is shit! where’s my headroom?!?! the frequency distribution of the music has also changed, DJ’s also got more concerned with jumping up and down and clapping rather than mixing and gain staging. Clubs started putting limiters on the systems 
Most of these kids doing EDM at high levels-really don’t even need ME’s at all! Their mix busses are so super complex. If they took that stuff off, I’d be totally lost. But they like a little analog processing in a lot of cases. Loudness, they *don’t need*
Clipping, limiting, whatever, it’s the modern thing- If i can help I can- and I tell them not to change a thing- just back off the limiter until the exact moment where the track loses the vibe. Then I go.

author: Rollmottle
content:
Just to clarify some terms for all the lurkers and for future reference...

The cutting engineer uses a lathe to make cuts. When you're making a record, you usually cut to an acetate first (aka "dubplate") to see how the cut fares. Acetates have a short life span and aren't entirely representative of the final product, but directionally enough to adjust as needed without using the more expensive material when you cut the actual master. Back in the vinyl days and up through even the early 2000s, DJ's were known to cut acetates to get their latest shit on something vinyl adjacent so it could be played in a set. Once an acetate is signed off on, the cutting engineer usually then cuts to a lacquer. The lacquer is what is sent off to plating and from there a father then a mother stamper is created and what is used to press your vinyl. A cutting engineer can also cut directly to a metal plate instead of a lacquer (DMM), which avoids the lacquer to father steps because the mother can be made from the DMM, but I'm not as familiar with this process.

TLDR if vinyl is important to you (it's not to everyone and that's ok - some bands just need merch to survive)

- HIre a Mastering Engineer who understands the format, the stages of production and can QC effectively

- Be realistic about what's possible

author: Berlin
content:
Reasons for Distortion in vinyl, to answer the question - @Zack Hames. There is literally an opportunity at every stage along the way for this to happen.. and so often finger pointing starts happening really fast in the line of production. It is very complex and every time something like this pops up, hopefully the Project Manager has been keeping tabs along the way and can pin point exactly when it arose.

1. Lacquer cut too loud across the board.

2. Lacquer cut too loud, but sounds fine on the outer edges, but as the needle moves to the middle/center, Inner Groove Distortion is introduced with the loss of resolution/IPS in playback. i.e. the outer grooves of a vinyl move about 20x faster under the needle than the inner grooves. Thus a loss in IPS toward the center - higher chance for distortion. That is historically why we put Bangers and Loud Tracks at the top/outside of a side and ballads or quieter songs on the inside of a side. That being said, can be avoided if just cut say, another 1db quieter. 

3. Issues with the stamper transfer/electro plating - dirty/contaminated baths.

4. Mishandling of the stampers at the record factory - not cleaned properly, dust is introduced.

5. Vinyl compound not heated to the right temperature at the extruder. 

6. Vinyl compound contaminated.

7. Too much regrind/recycled compound was incorporated into the raw vinyl compound.

8. Too much cooling was added to the record during the cooling cycle of the pressing process, so the record TEARS away from the stamper, often called "stitching" which also leads to distortion and pops. 

9. Mishandling at Packaging. 

10. The wind changed directions.

The list goes on and on. - Not to mention user/playback error. 

As @Nomograph Mastering it's a miracle it even works at all. Haha.

author: Berlin
content: Depending on the lathe and how much tech is being implemented, the visual spaces are created either manually by giving the carriage wheel a quick manual turn by hand, or manually pressing a button on the lathe console at the correct times - this advances/moves the cutter head carriage along. Some lathes have automation and it can all be done automatically, but more often times than not, it's still manual. The cutting engineer is watching the cutting time and doing it by hand.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. I immediately change the frequency graph to *Log* or *Extended Log*. This allows me to see the low-end and midrange with more resolution. It's the same reason most EQ graphs keep the octaves evenly spaced so that 50% of your freq graph isn't 10kHz and up. It gives you more resolution for the notes in the lower octaves.

As for FFT size or window shape, I never change it, but as Ruairi alluded to it requires an understanding of the physical limitations of FFT's. 

In short if you want very fine frequency information displayed you can change the window size and lose rhythmic information. But it you want very precise rhythmic visualization you have to sacrifice how much frequency information the FFT can display. So the ideal setting ultimately depends on what problem you're trying to solve.

I don’t know.  I literally only heard about these women in like the last 10 years or so.  They're all pioneers.  This is not to discount sexism...that exists...just more talking about why there aren't many of us in mastering for example.

author: Berlin
content:
I would suggest not changing the program material/main master too much and just preparing the sides, delivering one file per side, along with the PQ/Cut sheets with the track marker times (again one cut sheet per side), doing the QC listen down after export, and delivering with your approval.

I think backing off the limiter is sometimes OK, but very program material dependent. Yanking the limiter off a hot pop master might change things too much, for example.

Additionally, whoever is cutting the lacquer, will likely be doing their own adjustments as they see fit.. so if you are concerned about it translating properly, I would get with a lacquer engineer that you know and trust so you can have a dialogue about it, if needed.

That being said, in my experience, great sounding projects/masters will sound good on vinyl if the cutting engineer knows what they are doing… no matter how much you try to help with the PreMaster.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
In modern record making clipping and limiting on the buss is a huge part of the overall sound and feel of a record. Kendrick for example never heard his productions, mixes or masters without it. Clipping has an energy in the kicks and snares that was built a certain way, limiting has rounding and smoothing characteristics and often "holds" the track in a particular way. You can't just bypass one , or the other or both without huge changes in groove, balance, tone and feel. (Swapping limiters for something *safer* can be equally damaging) 

What does clipping actually do? It creates square waves at the extreme (for the duration of the clipping)

What is a square wave? It is a fundamental with a bunch of odd harmonics trailing off in level

What happens when you low pass the square wave at the converter reconstruction filter, lathe low pass etc? It is no longer a square wave

Does cutting this no longer square wave to a disc for brief periods present challenges and cause extra momentary distortion? Yes

Is that trade off worth while? I believe so and have itterated on this belief across hundreds and hundreds of projects cut and pressed to vinyl and then compared carefully with the original digital files

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The TLDR is that given the trade offs of the medium getting the big picture right (the overall tone, feel, groove and density of the production) matters more than the extra distortion added by cutting less than ideal waveforms to disc

author: Rollmottle
content:
I’ve found it easier to separate the tonal decisions from loudness decisions. I take the limiter out of the equation when I am making tonal decisions. So in my case, it's a simple bypass of with processing vs. without to make the decisions against the mix. This is inherently level matched. This gets trickier with dynamics processing but that’s a simple offset of the processed mix. That’s all happening on the object in my DAW without need for additional plugins or routing. Since I am rarely compressing anyways, this is a low friction way of judging the moves against the mix. 

When I’m happy with that, I’ll print the pre-lim and then load it up on another track to do the limiting. When I’m happy with the limiting, I have a quick action to create an A/B track where I can load the hot mix or mix to see if I’m as loud or louder than it. 

None of this is by number or meter. It’s all by ear.

author: Berlin
content: Digital "Vinyl Premasters" where an ME might mono sum the low end or not use a limiter, or do some of those types of "vinyl master" tricks, are honestly getting into the minutia and we are talking about 1-2% gains in the final result.. It should be mentioned also that the cutting engineer will also have their own cutting mastering chain of various outboard units that are going to try and catch some of those "issues" that might be presented. Best practice, and others might disagree with me, in my house is to prepare the vinyl sides and a PQ sheet, QC the export, and ship it. Don't fuck with an approved master/project too much. - Partner with a great lacquer engineer, and the Master will be dope.

author: Grover
content:
certain considerations have to be made re: low end, stereo width and minimal clipping (hard clipping we use in digital can blow up cutting heads) 
any old pressing house or engineer with a lathe can get a "fine" cut massaging these just a little. Some cheaper plants dont even bother QCing which is generally frowned upon. 

Those 2 (for a single 33 LP) ADM files Elaine mentioned are generally all that's needed with the limiter turned off. Otherwise process as you normally would (de-clicking if you love your cutting guys) 

In terms of getting a great sounding cut thats a more arcane and complex art and theres only a handful of dudes who cut the very best sounding stuff. @mcsnare is way deep in that world and may be able to comment more. (He cuts some amazing sounding stuff!)

author: Øra Mastering
content: I work both hybrid and itb. When working hybrid, I try to keep the same settings for a whole album and do eq, de-essing and level automation pre analog if needed (on individual tracks). On some albums, for me, there is no way around tweaking analog settings per track, but I try to avoid it. When printing the album I use the print-time to casually listen to the album from start to finish to catch stuff I would like to adjust (one track lacks impact ect.). Final limiter is always post analog print and I do not print hot. This makes revisions a breeze 97% of the time, unless there is a new mix of course. Also easy to back of a limiter without reprinting if the client wants more dynamics or I want a more dynamic vinyl pre-master. Hope that made sense.

author: Grover
content:
Well, a great sounding cut starts with good performances, mixes, etc. etc. just like any other medium. 

That said, if you've got a nice digital master (and these dont need to be loudenated like digital masters - the cutting engineer gets the level going onto the disk) then a cutting engineer isnt only massaging things so it can get cut, ideally not changing the sound. They may use a little eq, acceleration limiters or elliptical filters but they generally arent looking to change the basic sound, only make sure the head can cut it. The lathes collection of amps, the gear they have to accomplish this and the cutter head, the RIAA curve etc. will all heavily affect the sound, though that's probably obvious given that it's vinyl. The lathe amp/head combo can really make a pretty big difference. 
The Neumann VMS70's and 80's sound totally different from a Scully/Westrex with tube amps for example.

author: Berlin
content:
I skimmed through re: vinyl. I agree with @Nomograph Mastering here. The less fucking around with the approved Main Master, the better. Remember the Artist and team love and approved the Mains. 

A good dedicated cutting engineer will do what they need to do in terms of QC for a good transfer, but they aren’t looking to change the program material, just get it to transfer great.

Very Simply… 

1. Prepare Sides, one WAV per side

2. Export Wavs and PQ/Cut Sheets

3. QC WAVs and Cut Sheets

4. Deliver.

This will result in a record closest to what the team has already approved. 

From there you’re just getting away from the approved master and getting into taste/minutia/another approval round.

author: Grover
content:
Surely there's something to learn from the history though yes? Cutting is what the profession of mastering used to be and digital is not wholly removed. We can certainly take learnings from our history while embracing modern methods. Cutting good vinyl is also respect for the folks who work on it and the artists who want their music conveyed appropriately across mediums. 

I have no problem making stuff massively loud with zero limiting and small amounts of soft clipping, and still retaining tons of transient peaks. I prefer this sound to heavy limiting at the master stage where the program material audibly hits the limiter and the soundstage and sense of headroom collapses. To me, the limiter is optional, but I do understand many use it before they acquire the skills to work without it. 

That said, I also was taught that in genres where its appropriate (Imagine Dragons, Hip hop, EDM, etc.) that those sounds should go in at the production or mixing stage. At the mastering stage I was taught to do no harm, and only to enhance what was present. In my work pushing more than a few dB into a limiter to affect the groove of a piece does not track with my understanding of doing as little to change the sound as possible. But of course, it all depends on the project. My clients who make very mainstream pop/youtube music don't particularly care if I radically editorialize as long as it sounds good and serves the tune. 

There's also something to be said for music which needs to be quiet. Not all music should be loudenated to within an inch of its life. Not all music needs quiet and intimacy. I think of we hold the pursuit of "the program material's individual requirements to be king" we cannot then also dismiss vinyl as unimportant or say that one MUST always do things a particular way.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
My 2 cents -- going forward those of us who think of mastering as "finishing" instead of "mastering" in the traditional sense might be very well equipped. I know Edsel you are similar -- but when I let go of the "this is what mastering IS" mindset, and leaned into the "this is the box in front of me I have to operate within", things got much better. Acceptance.

Is it mastering if I only work from a stereo file? A limited REF? Tearing apart an mp3 bounce with AI and remaking it? An Ableton session? I say yes to all if we are the ones getting the record across the line. 

That said, the traditional approach is IMO the best for many reasons, but in some sense just having a stereo file is an almost arbitrary restriction based on how projects are made and shared (though a good one). But as technology evolves and shifts, best to be on the cutting edge of knowing how to make a lot of situations work -- I bet the winners will be those who do

author: Val ᶠʳ
content:
Here are my scripts to generate PQ sheets for CDs and Vinyls : 
It's very customized for the workflow I've described, and it's made with ChatGPT and dirty personal tweaks so I can't guarantee it will work smoothly everywhere.
For vinyl, the script is looking for regions in the project in order to define the different "Sides" of the vinyl, and then markers for songs timing references, ISRCs etc.
So I add regions in the session, named : "Side A", "Side B" etc. and export them as .wav, alongside the Cue Sheet.

author: mcsnare
content: It’s not that the grooves are more narrow, they aren’t. It’s that the rotational speed slows down from the outside to the inside. The last 4 or 5 mins have the same amount of squiggles compressed into a shorter area. It’s not a cutting problem it’s a problem playing it back. The needle on your turntable can’t physically trace that much movement in a shorter period of time that occur on the end of the record. Think of it as if the outside starts at 30 IPS tape speed and by the end it’s slowed to like 7.5 IPS.

author: Rollmottle
content:
The things to check vary based on the requested deliverables. If you’re not really doing this regularly, for you, I'd make sure you’re asking up front if there are alts or files for physical releases that you need to account for. Cleans, instrumentals, acapellas, sequence, overlapping crossfades, metadata, PQ sheets, less lims, vinyl, etc. all may start to matter to finalizing something. And if you haven’t accounted for the deliverable and the time it takes to prep and QC in your rates, well you may be in for some pain.

Others may have some of these steps in different spots, but for me, it's roughly:

1. Print approved masters at native sample rate and bit depth.
1a. < Deprecate un-used versions>
1b.  <SRC/dither to any other sample rates and bit depth requested>
1c. <Assemble any physical deliverables>
2. Listen to every single file you’ve printed & check any data
3. Deliver

author: Grover
content:
I have worked with several of the top cutters in the USA and it was routine practice to remove the limiter if the engineer doing the cutting was the same one doing the digital. 

If there is still hard clipping in your master then the cutting engineer is more likely to need to use acceleration limiters to soften the peaks and in my view is forcing them to change the sound more than just removing the limiter. Still, you technically can submit that way if you like.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Let's assume a few things

a) The artist loves their digital masters

b) Limiting and clipping cause challenges in cutting and more importantly playing back vinyl

It's a fact that we push most modern records to the limit loudness wise and they often beneift sonically from a few dB more breathing room.

So here I start with a default of 2dB less limiting. I'm comparing back and forth with the approved digital masters attenuated to match. Is it better? Is some element popping out?

author: hebakadry
content: I think time spent de-essing vocals and treating HF content in vinyl prepped masters overrides worrying about how much limiting there is in my opinion. The amount of limiting and how good/bad the cut is really pertinent on the program material itself.  Not the actual amount of gain reduction you are doing because the cutter will literally just turn everything down anywhere between 8-10dB before the signal hits the amps. Excessive sibilance, on a hyper compressed rock record with insane splashy over compressed cymbals and out of control HF information will result in the dull cuts you get back from most plants where you don’t have access to the cutting engineer.  They do this because they want to create a playback safe record and avoid a very expensive $10k mistake like blowing a cutterhead if their amp breakers aren’t calibrated right.  Instead of spot de-essing problem on one song or spot treating problem songs on a side, they will opt for broad stroke moves (HF limiting, EQ, global de-essing) and that can be a bit of death sentence to the quality of the cut and put everyone off vinyl as a format.  Which I think is an incredible format with well crafted engineering.  Also I strongly believe that every record doesn’t belong on vinyl…but that’s another convo.

author: hebakadry
content: If you don’t cut and you’re not sure... keep the limiting and let the cutter solve the issues.  If you have a relationship with a cutting engineer and want to see what works best, have them send an acetate where they cut a side with the limiter on full blast and the same exact program on another side with it pulled back and make a determination.  Transcribe the sides into your DAW and then flip between them and see what sounds best.  Don’t compare to the digital master…just use your ears.  Good cutting engineers are creative and may do some work to give you the “transparent” cut everyone’s after.  But it does require some crafty engineering and taste.

author: Berlin
content:
Prepare, QC after Export and Provide 1 WAV file per side, leave all transitions intact.
Prepare, QC after Export and Provide 1 PQ/Track Marker sheet per side - Use track start times on the side, not track lengths.. This is what the cutting engineer will use to make track markers when cutting.

The spaces between songs on the surface of the disc are visual markers only. Those will be created by the cutting engineer. Audio can run through the "spaces" as the groove is one long groove, start to finish.

author: Val ᶠʳ
content:
My Reaper workflow is to use the DDP marker formatting for every format's renders. (DDP, .wav, .mp3, even vinyl, etc...) 

Let's say you have your track markers formatted as : **#TITLE=songtitle|PERFORMER=artist|ISRC=666** etc., aside of the "!" marker at the beginning for the 2sec gap and the last "@" marker for the album metadata.
Your session is now ready for a DDP export.
Then, if you want to render .mp3 and/or .wav you have to use the wildcard : **$marker(#TITLE)[|]** in the file name entry, aside to other wildcards you'll need for folder structures etc. Also, the options :  "Bounds : All project markers" and "do not render files that are likely silent" are needed and will prevent rendering the empty first 2 sec marker.
To automatically include metadata in the files, you can use the same wildcards such as : **$marker(#TITLE)[|]** for Title,** $marker(PERFORMER)[|]** for Artist, **$marker(ISRC)[|]** for ISRC, etc etc...

With this method, you can, with one single workflow, render : DDPs, digital formats, and even vinyl, using additional regions. Once you have everything ready in render presets, it's super easy.
I recommend using the "WyattRice DDP editor" to easily edit the markers.
I've also made a script to automatically generate a .html "PQ sheet" file with timings, titles, ISRCs, etc, (both CD and Vinyl)

I hope it can help, English is not my native language, so feel free to ask for clarifications if needed.

author: Jodonny
content:
Haha, I don’t think anyone here is debating what the key filter is doing in the Pro-C. 

And that is not the same as using a multiband comp to compress just the mids. A comp with a key to trigger the compressor with just mids in there is still going to compress the bass frequencies and highs. It’s compressing the entire mix. A multiband would only compress the mids if setup that way.

author: hebakadry
content: Very quick take on the vinyl gripes some people have.  I am of the younger cutting generation and I can definitely assure you guys that cutting engineers today are way better than the nostalgia people have about cutting “back in the day”.  We have amazing tools now…plugins to manually de-ess the program material cutting engineers get from mastering engineers that have had ZERO sibilance mitigation, totally blasted material at -6LUFS with clipped transient information, distortion, you name it….we actually have tools now to fix these issues that people 20 years ago had only one knob to process it.  We even had a tiny amount of innovation on pitch computers which were last made in the early 80s.  That being said..there has been very little innovation in lathes otherwise…we are still working with lathes from 1970 or earlier because literally NO ONE has been able to improve upon the sheer magnitude of incredible feat of engineering lathe machines that Neumann and Scully made 50 years ago.  There have been kickstarters…many many dudes tried, they literally all failed.

author: hebakadry
content: If however you’re cutting at a plant like GZ media or any of their brokers (which everyone does now) for the high turnaround, where you cannot interface with the cutting engineer…yes you’re going to get a boring “safe cut”…meaning they will not go above and beyond or be creative and will avoid inner diameter distortion at all cost.  They have their own proprietary software and the lathe operator is literally in a different room from the person that actually processes the source material they get for the cut. Very much a setup made for speed factory cutting & efficiency and not so much for the craft.  There is an interesting video by Michael Fremer filmed at GZ…i think he’s the only person that was ever allowed in and it is by all means is an impressive operation.  They have a pretty advanced QC process.  But it’s a game of odds on whether your cut will sound good or not.  Half the time you’ll get a shit cut and the other time it might be fine…depends on which operator you get.  It’s treated like a product there and not so much a “craft”.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
What @hyanrarvey and others said...but usually this is used to get a bounce with the compression to make sure it is releasing in time with the groove. In gridded stuff like hip-hop you can actually be really mathematic with it, but generally you don't need to it's about the feel. Of course every compressor is different even with the same "settings"...you can set the attack to let enough transient in and the release to basically make the compressor return to "zero" in time with the movement of the groove. But the release shape, etc will definitely play a role in this too

At least this is how I'm usually using it (though very rarely compressing at all, and when I do I'm using the Weiss DS1-Mk3 plug which has complicated release characteristics). Feel free to correct me if I'm off the mark on this! It is about feel and making the record pump in a pleasing way which can add energy. But of course it's helpful to be very specific about what part of the groove you're actually wanting to bring out (or back) so to me it's hugely about your gut reaction to how the groove moves you

author: Rollmottle
content:
i take the 1 master to rule them all approach so the approval on the digital master is the approval on the master that will be used to cut from. what you get back from the vinyl mastering process, be it in the form of a lacquer or a test press would be up for QC to see how the cut fared. notes would go back to the cutting engineer to adjust. what i wouldn't do, is PRE-adjust the digital master or provide some other version of the mix to "guess" at the moves needed to be made to translate a mix/master onto vinyl. i leave that in the hands of the cutting engineer.

i think the reality is, most vinyl now is a "flat cut" from whatever you send them unless you're working with an ME who is also the cutting engineer, who can shepherd the entire project across the finish line.

author: Rollmottle
content: the other reality is, "QC" on vinyl is happening once the entire run is in hand and it's too late to really do anything about it. 😂 😭

author: Gazing Wrmth | Mixes & Masters
content:
Also like I have got fairly comfortable with compression now while doing rough masters 
Correct me If I'm wrong but what I'll usually do while compressing masters is setting the attack time around 60-80ms to let the initial transient and release to 400-600ms to only clamp on what's in between Kicks
This usually gives me A Good result with 4 on the floor stuff but I don't know how to approach songs which is not 4 on the floor(eg. Hip Hop,Future Bass). I'll get the Attack time Right but again I get confused on how to go for setting the release time. Then I Usually Go by ear and hope that whatever I Did is not wrong for that perticular song
And limiter is something I'm still confused about conceptually.
Although I do set them in a way so that I don't lose the knock of my kicks and Groove and still maintain a healthy level but I still fail to understand what exactly is happening because what I know till now is the release settings in limiters behave differently then compressors so it's always confusing.
So I'm still get lost in this rabbit hole sometimes which makes me question my legitimacy😂😂

author: ALXCPH
content: Think about why you are compressing? And then Think about the result you get from compressing the material and if that is what you were looking for when you reached for the compressor.

author: Zack Hames
content:
That said - at the level that you, Matt, Cian, Jon, and every other person who’s been on the live, youre not getting completely fucked mixes.

A lot of us still get mixes or recordings that are not fully realized. I know some people in here have said they’d never edit or tune what they were given to mix. There was a time that’s what I spent the majority of my time doing because it was unlistenable until I did. (Happens less and less now 🙂 ) #
I mastered a track recently, the vocal reverb was so whack. They didn’t EQ the reverb at all, it was insanely sibilant just in the reverb, etc. you guys know what I’m talking about. The artist mixed it themself and they’re NOT a mixer, so I kindly prodded and got her to EQ it out. She was thankful and it made it significantly better. 

Also, I did use compression on the bus on that master - but I would never expect a mastering engineer to put that on my mix because I’m compressing my mix already.  

Mixing pop, mixing well produced tracks from seasoned folks who make decisions well before the mixer is involved, is way different than mixing a local bands home recorded ep. Both need totally different perspectives and tools and focuses.

This got derailed…point is, my view on mastering’s role has changed dramatically since listening to LWMR. I hope I never have to “master” my own own mixes again because  I think it’s fundamentally, in some ways, not even truly mastering.

I think that is a little bit of a simple answer. 


Art is something we create to the best of our abilities. If someone feels something is exactly how it should sound, is it not finished or good enough?

Imagine you are a painter, once you are satisfied with your painting you don’t necessarily go to someone else to finish it for you.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Ok, a few thoughts

- In mainstream vinyl production there has to be a vinyl cutting engineer, it’s a technical and challenging process (there are very niche ways of making “vinyl” than don’t use traditional cutting but you can ignore)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: - A good cut is just the start, plating matters a lot and then of course pressing (the whole thing is just a giant pain in the ass for me)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: 1) A lot of people remove the limiters and clippers all together for the vinyl cutting masters, this makes zero sense to me and most modern records are unrecognizable when you do that

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: 2) De-essing matters - I’ll often do some extra spot de-essing on the vinyl masters and if there is a challenging track I’ll note it on cutting notes

author: Rollmottle

But a little more dynamic range does nice things, but on almost all modern projects if I go beyond 2 dB less limiting things shift - snares pop too much etc. I check *everytime* I make vinyl masters so there’s a lot of reps on it

author: Eric Martin
content: I think for me, in my specific case, the masters are likely ship-able for vinyl as is, I’ve done it before with success because the ME’s did the job well and this records aren’t that loud.

author: cian riordan
content: I may not have your reps, but I have yet to have an album come across my desk that I prep for vinyl that doesn’t sound better with 5 dB less limiting. I get that our line of work is constantly trying to shovel shit rolling down the hill at us, but I think there’s more nuance than “modern records are loud and need to stay loud otherwise they fall apart.” Vinyl isn’t a medium that was designed with -7 or -9 LUFS in mind… and I have yet to hear a vinyl pressing cut in this contemporary fashion that doesn’t sound like a pile of assholes. I have lots of time for serving the client and the project, being a team player and getting things across the line.. but that’s usually the reality of the business... not what’s best for the Sonics. I think vinyl has the opportunity to sound amazing but modern mixing AND mastering techniques are often getting in the way of that.

author: cian riordan

author: hebakadry
content: Also you have to remember most cuts are being cut by engineers at cutting plants where the processing happens in a separate rooms from where the actual lathe is…it’s very “factory” and they will really not go above and beyond to solve issues except just literally turning down the master even more, HF limiting and de-essing the hell out of it’s life.

author: hebakadry
content: If you're not sure...I would lean on the cutting engineer to decide the crossover point on the elliptical EQ...because not all low freq phase needs to be entirely eliminated and that can be v detrimental to your mix/master.  Some can be totally fine...let them decide how it should be controlled instead of doing something super extreme on your end.

author: hebakadry
content: There's the wonderful Simulathe plugin...I cannot express how amazing this tool is.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But ultimately it’s trivial to level match and compare and limit less and less until you hit what you consider to be unacceptable changes (knowing that most vinyl masters are never approved by the artist)

author: hebakadry
content: If you have a relationship with a cutting engineer and a project with a budget for example…have them do a dub either on a song (both cut in the same spot on each side) or a whole side…with limiting and without…or a few dB less where the dynamics remain intact.  And see how you feel about it.  Or run it through simulathe and preview how it sounds on various playback cartridges.

author: cian riordan
content: Cmon, no-ones saying you need to sit people down and lecture them. I also don’t know of anybody looking for “loud” when they hire sometime to master something for vinyl. I think the approach for two different mediums are getting conflated here. All I’m trying to say is — yes, a quieter unlimited/less limited mix might sound different, but it might also sound better. That’s clearly not the case in the majority of stuff that comes across your desk. But nobody is strapping on their neckbeard here looking to lecture folks… I think you can have good intentions reaching back to artist/mixer for more dynamic mixes. It’s not a “Brian Lucey, I know better” kinda deal.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Oh, I was off the vinyl convo

author: hebakadry
content: Lecturing artists condescendingly sucks but some are unaware (and some very clued in- which is always nice).  There are physical & geometric limitations when it comes to cutting LPs that make it very frustrating to a lot of engineers (understandably so)…but some information about the format does indeed help.

author: hebakadry
content: 1. more dynamics, 2. treated sibilance, 3. shorter sides, and 4. smarter sequencing…those are all good things to know about.  And if you’re at the forefront of that as a mastering engineer you will certainly have a better sounding cut, especially if you make very informed decisions about where it’s cut, plated and sometimes bargaining with the label about where it’s pressed.  It empowers the artist to know they have some control on how their LP will sound instead of just throwing hands up in the air and saying modern vinyl sucks, which is not true.

author: nachomaquieira
content:
Hey folks! I always read and learn from the great stuff you share around here, and I thought it'd be cool to share something out of the ordinary that I did today for this particular situation. I was tasked with mastering a r&b/pop song with a kick and 808 really upfront, but they weren't cutting through or punching in the low/mids due to lack of EQ on the kick and saturation on the 808. (And no time to make corrections!)

To fill in what was missing, I tried a few things, but what worked best for me to address both issues was sending it to a parallel devil-loc (which is killer for adding low-mids and saturation), and using the Ozone imager to make it only sound from 500Hz downwards and make it mono. Luckily, they sent me the music and the lead vocals separately, so I was able to do this without compromising the vocal color. For this particular situation, it worked beautifully. Cheers!

author: Soundswithsammy
content: Hey everybody! A question about mastering for Vinyl? Should 808 based hiphop be handled any differently (dithering or otherwise) when mastering for Vinyl? Would the grooves handle the 808s I add to them, as long as the digital master is good?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: We know that lots of albums have been made with 808s over many decades so for sure hip hop on vinyl works

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Who is cutting your vinyl?

author: Berlin
content: It's not how deep your low end is, but how in phase it is down there with those 808s on vinyl. I would consult with your cutting engineer, but they likely have an elliptical EQ in their mastering chain to clean up out of phase sub frequencies - common practice. That being said, if your 808s are panned or have alot of stereo/out of phase information, the result of the cut will likely differ from your digital master. - Again, I'd talk it through with your cutting engineer, if you can! a real convo if you can and not just going by a one-size-fits-all spec sheet from a manufacturer.

author: Rollmottle
content:
There’s a couple of really dumb threads on GS Mastering right now where the idea of “spreading the load” is the key to mastering glory. I’m sure at some point in early digital and lower headroom analog, it maybe may have had some validity…? In 2024 it makes no intellectual and logical sense to me.

All things being equal, isn’t compressing a signal with two separate processors both set to 1.5:1 not the same as just compressing with one of them at 3:1? “Spreading the load” makes no sense and I don’t get it. Seems like a justification for over-processing and gear wankery. Am I missing something?

author: Ted Whitten Media
content:
Yeah last time I talked to Scott Hull, he basically told me "just make it sound good". There are of course lots of nitty gritty things to get the most out of a record, but the cutting engineer can worry about that, any Kentucky windage on your part will probably just make it sound worse. 

Fwiw, he also mentioned that for every dB of limiting you can expect a dB or more lower on the cut, so that noise floor will start to get annoying. They can actually cut the unlimited stuff quite a bit louder, so unless you need that limiter for the sound, maybe consider ditching it or at least hitting it less.

content:
Why do some vinyl masters sound distorted and bad, and some others don’t?

I’m listening to a remix/remaster of the album “Magnified” by Failure. Ken Andrews is the guy who did all of it (also primary songwriter of Failure) and the mixes have some wins, but there’s this weird layer of distortion over everything. I’ve noticed this on another vinyl from the band Title Fight, which I found unlistenable. To me it read as “super loud digital master meant for streaming/CD slammed onto vinyl”

Is it simply the master files used? The pressing?  The vinyl itself? The failure record is a color vinyl vs black vinyl? Anyone else have some strong ideas about this?

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Zack Hames
content:
I've only mastered one thing that made it to vinyl, and I was pleasently surprised with the results, so in my mind I'm like "how hard could it be to not fuck it up on the engineering end?" if I managed to pull it off...

but, of course, there are a MILLION variables. and from what I understand, a lot of times, the cutting engineer or whoever can simply turn the audio file down so it doesn't fucking slam into the vinyl. Maybe some people do this, and some people don't?

i know absolutely *nothing* about this other than surface level. But I'm sure someone who knows what they're doing and takes the time can at least mitigate those issues, rather than a place that may simply dump your audio onto a vinyl without listeing to it. (is that a thing? certainly it must be)

anyway thanks for the answers, I appreciate it. Vinyl is a really fun medium to listen on and to experience even if's a crapshoot

author: Eric Martin
content:
I think the cutting engineers job has to turn it down so that the cutting head doesn’t jump, but from my understand just turning down a crazy limited digital mastering is going to result in a bad sounding vinyl, I could be way off, but a cutting/mastering engineer that I work with essentially told me the best practice prep is to EQ and level for a master but don’t limit or compress if the mixes were already compressed sounding, the end result vinyl will sound better that way.

I recently did exactly this and mastered a record essentially to -16 doing the EQ that made things sound right but didn’t limit at all because it didn’t need it, and the cutting engineer will do the transfer.

author: Zack Hames
content: This is what I did for vinyl masters - just turned off the limiter that was making it competitively loud, seemed to work great. kind of like what I'd give an ME for a final mix!

author: Zack Hames
content:
I feel like some of these sound like, simply turned down digital masters (that were limited to hell)

and some, there's a distinct distortion on top that doesn't sound like clipping, it sounds way harder and weird, this is the thing i keep noticing, and why I am wondering if it had nothing to do with the file itself, but rather it being cut too loud onto the vinyl.

anyway; good to know your experience is similar.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Yeah, PHM is a phenomenal record bc of the songs and the sounds Trent created, not the mix or master. But, from a simply technical standpoint, this 2011 reissue sounds like the fucking music without any weird distortion and weird peaking bullshit, which is what I’m getting specifically annoyed with. 

A few bands have done this - MBV being one, Hum remixed “Downward is Heavenward” seemingly the same way, all analog all the way, original tapes remixed, etc. the vinyl sounds terrific. But I don’t think the all analog is the why, I think it’s the fact that they gave a shit and made sure it was right. 

That’s why I was shocked about this Failure record, because it’s a similar approach all around from a guy who seemingly cared a lot about it.

author: Elaine Rasnake
content:
Generally when I've had to master files for someone to press to vinyl, I will take the limiter off and create  designated A side / B Side files along with a PQ sheet of all of the start/stop times, album order, and things like that via HOFA DDP Maker.
I leave all of the high end low end adjustments to the pressing engineer since they will know best what needs to be adjusted, if at all. 

I know of some folks who also just send the limited "digital distro" files but I prefer to give a more dynamic version and the pressing engineer can adjust it.

Usually an artist will go through test pressings and if there are issues, usually (or at least ideally) the pressing engineer, the artist, and the mastering engineer are all communicating about things and next steps

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: That's the general wisdom I've seen online. I'm just confused about the overall process. Does the cutting engineer do additional processing (essentially QCing and fixing your work) or are they just cutting what you sent in? For pressing plants that accept digital files are they using an in house cutting engineer or is there then no cutting engineer?

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Is the cutting engineer usually the one that creates the premaster?

author: Elaine Rasnake
content: Ahhh in terms of the process of the pressing engineer. It all depends on the place where it gets cut. I know some artists who have used some pressing plants that strictly take the file and slap it onto the vinyl without any consideration for it sounding good (cheap and quicks) but other places have engineers who will QC, and go the whole nine yards to adjust it to make it sound its best on the disc.

author: Grover
content:
If that much limiting is happening then sure, it's part of the music. My experience is mainly with two situations:

1. The digital mastering engineer is the same as the cutting engineer. Artists were not bypassed in getting the vinyl cut approved. They listened to and signed off on both. 

2. The digital and cutting engineer were working closely together. 

Now, a lot of these artists were not making music that required massive amounts of limiting to sound the way they do. 

That said, I disagree. Vinyl is already changing the sound so radically that if sonic faithfulness to the digital master is required - why make vinyl? A record will NEVER sound like the digital original or even the tape master for that matter. No two lathes sound anything alike, and the differences can be astonishing. I have heard a lathe amp turn a wretched sounding track into a brilliant one. And vice versa. Vinyl is an unfaithful medium. If you don't care about the cut's sound that's fine. Submit whatever is submitted for the digital master and let the pressing house sort it out. Why even bother with a proper 3rd party cutting engineer at that point?

author: Grover
content: I suppose the philosophy as I understand is that the vinyl cutting engineer is much like the digital mastering engineer. Trying to preserve as faithfully as possible, but also dealing with the fact that they will have to alter the sound.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: My experience has always been that vinyl “premaster” files get sent in and 6 months later it’s released

author: Grover
content: Everyone does things differently and it depends a bit on the artist/label how involved they want to get on making the vinyl release sound good. An absence of feedback usually means an Absence of complaints though 🙂

author: Grover
content:
Bob and Ian's opinions on "audiophiley" music are of no functional interest to me. I'm not advocating for that in either digital or vinyl mastering. 

And I get it - I know and have worked with several really talented and very busy cutting engineers, and I take it seriously as well. 

A question was asked regarding how to prepare masters. A good friend of mine is one of the top Lathe techs in North America, and my understanding from him and the cutting engineers I know and have worked with, is that digital clipping can make life hard for lathes. I'm not saying you cannot do it or arguing the merits of digital limiting or anything like that, that's an entirely separate topic. It is however a technical fact that lathes do not get along well with digital clipping and it will make the cutting engineers job harder and generally result in a record which does not sound as dynamic. If that is an acceptable compromise then so be it. As you say, if the artist/client is happy and the bills are paid, then all is well (mostly 😉)

author: hebakadry
content: Distortion is very rarely an issue of the pressing or mastering, most distortion is actually playback distortion ( it is not a signal on the record but rather a signal that emerges as an artefact throughout playback).  Cutting vinyl is pretty much a constant balancing act between preserving the sonic identity of the music and delivering a ‘playback-safe’ record.

author: mcsnare
content:
Hip hop is almost unique in the limiting being a huge technical aspect of the genre. I continue to master hip hop although I have not as of yet, cut any. 
My standard procedure for making a digital master for lacquer cutting is simply to render the sides without limiting. 
Ive have had exactly one client that thought the test pressing sounded too dynamic so I resent the files but with some limiting retained although not the full monte. If you heard the music you would have NEVER guessed this twist in the story. 
@hebakadry is correct that highs are a bigger deal. I guess the point is every project has unique characteristics that require the person cutting it to sometimes make decisions that blur technical and artistic ones together. This is partly why I have a policy of cutting only masters I’ve done. I feel I have the liberty of eq’ing some more at cutting time. 
So as far as the comments go, nobody is totally wrong - it’s simply very situation dependent. I would advise a few things:.

author: Berlin
content:
All of my experience cutting has been on lacquers. There are very few (maybe zero) DMM lathes in the states that are doing commercial work (most of them are privately owned by the Church of Scientology). DMM is much more prevalent overseas.

One benefit to my understanding is that DMM is a bit more cost effective (Skipping a mother/father step at plating) and also, the DMM piece is not a sacrificial piece, but can be used/plated again and again.. unlike a lacquer which is likely trashed after silvering and electroplating (sometimes no, but most times yes).

Sonically, I'm sure, cutting has the same goal, for a great transfer.

author: Berlin
content:
Vinyl itself has its own limitations, and most of them are in the playback, and not the cutting. The groove can contain much more information than the playback needle can handle (i.e. out of phase sub signals - they can likely be cut, but they can't be played back well on most systems). - I say that to say that Lacquer can handle anything that you want to give it. 

My suggestion is to link up with a cutting engineer - whether lacquer or DMM, communicate your sonic desires, and let them do their work. If you can find someone great that's local to you, perhaps you can attend and put your ears on a test cut.

author: Ted Whitten Media
content:
Does anyone have any documentation on marker/region formatting for Reaper, especially when making DDP's? There doesn't seem to be anything specific in the manual, and I've found conflicting info online. Specifically, there's two things I can't figure out for sure...

-can I put the album @ tag in the two second gap between the initial ! tag and the first # track tag? Or does it need to go at the end?

-can I add a duplicate TITLE= entry in the region/marker for rendering purposes and have the DDP still turn out fine? Render wildcards don't recognize the #title like the DDP does.

author: Mike Tierney
content:
I master in Reaper and can maybe help here, but these might be in the fuck around and find out category–

1) I've always done the @ tag at the end. I'm not sure if it needs to be but I'm curious what the advantage would be in not having it at the end? You could always export a mock DDP though and re-import to see if the metadata holds. Better yet, import it into a different DDP playing software just in case

2) for # title, I don't think making a region with the title for the sake of rendering wildcards will affect the DDP; I think the DDP metadata only looks at markers. Again, I would make a DDP and reimport it to check...

...but setting a title is a surprisingly easy script, depending on your naming convention. For example, I usually name my session files to be [date] [project].RPP. So it would look like "20250902 Example.RPP". I have a little script that automatically sets the Title metadata in the Project Settings window whenever I hit render based on my naming convention. So you could maybe tweak it to fit your naming convention/needs, but that tends to work pretty well for me and is actually even a little easier than making a separate region

author: aliberger
content: hey all, i have a q about order of operations for SRC & bit depth reduction when turning in masters for different formats, which somehow i'm doing for a client for the first time today. the premasters for this project came in at 24/48 except for two remixes at 24/44. i did the digital masters at the original sample rates, they've been approved and now i also need to send 16/44 for a cd and 24/48 as 2 full sides for a tape

author: aliberger
content: i guess i'm concerned about dithering twice and wondering if it makes more sense to re-export at 32-bit and use that as the basis for the cd and tape versions

author: Berlin
content:
If you want you can implement 2x oversampling to help mitigate ISP a little, but if you wanted a little more control, you can upsample and work at that high sample rate. Export at that higher sample rate, and 32bit float.

SRC and Dither using RX for your various formats.

Reassemble in your DAW for each program. i.e. Main Master, DDP, or Vinyl Premaster.

Find a workflow that works for
you.

Lots of folks don’t worry about these things and just export, listen and party. 🎉

author: Val ᶠʳ
content: I've often thought about something similar for sidechain purposes. Like, when a vocal is quiet, you might want more compression on the targeted material, (to hear the vocal better) than when the vocal is louder it's sometimes already cutting enough through the mix.

author: oaklandmatt
content: I got sent a samply link for a vinyl master. Is there any real value and listening to a digital file of a vinyl master? I already approved a digital master a month or two ago, but they've just done a mastering for vinyl

author: DarrenB
content: For me the biggest reason is object based plugins (and then further the ability to split the object and have different settings on that if needed).  The DDP and metadata stuff isn't as necessary anymore but handy to have all in one place.

author: Berlin
content:
Similar to @DarrenB. Using Object Based processing is a workflow that I particularly enjoy. Just a different approach, Wavelab also has a lot of tools included for preparing and exporting different final deliverables like creating a DDP or easily exporting PQ sheets for Vinyl Sides. 

All of those things can be achieved using multiple different tools, after processing audio in PT.

author: matthewrederburg
content:
Hey everyone, question for the brain trust.

I'm mixing a record that's getting a vinyl release. The mastering engineer has requested, via the client, "audio provided as.wav files, consolidated to side A and side B, with cue sheet labeling all the track markers."

To me, the consolidation + cue sheet creation seems like the responsibility of mastering. I'm guessing that there was a communication error and the ME isn't aware that the band wants to hire him for multiple services - mastering thru vinyl prep and lacquer cutting.

What do we think?

author: matthewrederburg
content: Thank you, that's helpful. Not a lot of my clients make physical records and I wanted to be sure that I wasn't missing a responsibility as a mixer.
